content:
Hello @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will take place in about 2h
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

Scheduled checkins from:

  • WG-rfc-2229 by @nikomatsakis @Matthew Jasper (if the WG still active, else perhaps remove it from the rotation?)
  • WG-rls2.0 by @matklad: anyting to share?
Hi @T-compiler/meeting , time for weekly triage meeting. Add a :wave: to show you’re here!
Thanks to @WG-prioritization and especially @apiraino for their work on the agenda

We’ll start off with ~5 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow 2021-12-17T15:00:00+01:00, monthly Compiler Team Planning meeting
(We do not currently have any meeting proposals, but I am sure I have had recent conversations where great ideas for meetings came up. So, I’ll try to go find those and write up proposals.)

• Reminder: if you see a PR/issue that seems like there might be legal implications due to copywrite/IP/etc, please let the Core team know (or at least message pnkfelix or Wesley Wiser so we can pass it along).
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • No new proposals this time.

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "CI should exercise (subset of) tests under --stage 1" compiler-team#439 (last review activity: 3 months ago)
    • "Accept pc in place of unknown and unknown in place of pc for x86_64 and i?86 targets" compiler-team#441 (last review activity: 5 months ago)
    • "Make -Z binary-dep-depinfo the default behavior" compiler-team#464 (last review activity: 2 months ago)
    • "Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc)" compiler-team#472 (last review activity: about 6 days ago)
    • "-Dwarnings to cover all warnings" compiler-team#473 (last review activity: about 6 days ago)
(I have a standing action item for myself to push forward on compiler-team#439)

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Stabilize -Z instrument-coverage as -C instrument-coverage" rust#90132
    • "Stabilize -Z print-link-args as -C print-link-args" rust#91606

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Tracking issue for RFC 2115: In-band lifetime bindings" rust#44524
(rust#44524 is an FCP to close the issue, if I recall correctly. So its a pretty easy thing to check your box on)

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.
(suggestion: link to the specific FCP comments in the FCP parts of the agenda?)
Good idea. @apiraino would that be hard to automate? (How much of agenda is still being constructed by hand?)
(Is it all of it, apart from initial static template?)

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Stabilise feature(const_generics_defaults)" rust#90207
    • "rustdoc: accept --out-dir and soft-deprecate --output" rust#91260
WG checkins

pnkfelix said:

Good idea. apiraino would that be hard to automate? (How much of agenda is still being constructed by hand?)

I'll look into it, it's 85% automated
For @WG-rfc-2229 , we have no update. At the last checkin, @nikomatsakis suggested shutting the WG down. So we should probably do that.
For @WG-rls2.0 , I think there are some things to report, or that will be reported in the near future.
but I don’t have anything concrete to note here at this time
(wow that really looked like a waste of words, doesn’t it…)

Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

• "Deduplicate projection sub-obligations" rust#90423
    • fixes rust#91598, a P-critical compile-time regression
I'm hesitant about bwckporting anything related to projection caching
Because of all the issues that we've had
That being said, I think this PR is pretty safe
And the regression is quite bad
regressions: #91598, #89195, #89601, ...
I'm comfortable backporting because of the new test added
We are early in the release cycle
so I think I’m cool with a beta backport
I’m more hestitant about a stable backport, but we’re not discussing that yet
@Jack Huey PR #90423 doesn’t add any new test?
(is there a different PR that does so that we should also backport?)
or, wait, do you mean “test” as in “if condition”, not a regression/unit test?
I guess we could add the test to backport too
I added tests in #91065
Okay. Lets plan to backport #90423 and #91065 in tandem
beta-accepted.

• "Sync portable-simd to remove autosplats" rust#91484
    • PR provided by @Jubilee
    • fixes rust#90904, P-high regression in libs from stable
So @Vadim Petrochenkov clarified what their issues were
yeah, I think this is clear for backport imo
and @Jubilee responded with an acknowledgement
@simulacrum did @Vadim Petrochenkov ’s concerns get addressed?
I don't think this should be labeled T-compiler. Nothing outside of library/ changes. Seems like T-libs should decide if they want to backport or not.
ah, yes, in https://github.com/rust-lang/portable-simd/pull/212
the likely strategy for backport may be removing the module entirely

Wesley Wiser said:

I don't think this should be labeled T-compiler. Nothing outside of library/ changes. Seems like T-libs should decide if they want to backport or not.

I was wondering that, too. So T-compiler does not decide for T-libs backports, correct?

simulacrum said:

the likely strategy for backport may be removing the module entirely

that would still be a T-libs decision, right?
sure, potentially
but there is no PR that does that yet, either, right?
well, it'd likely get done as part of the backport rollup
okay

So, actions here are: 1. reclassify #91484 as T-libs, not T-compiler, and 2. post a comment that we think some backport is justified here, though we as a team recommend just removing the module entirely ?
Does that sound right?
oh: T-libs, or T-libs-api ?
T-libs I think

pnkfelix said:

oh: T-libs, or T-libs-api ?

never really understood the difference, tbh :shrug:
I'm unsure ... but I suppose tagging either will probably get the attention of the correct set of people.
@apiraino T-libs-api is concerned with the API’s that are presented to the world from our std library
@apiraino while T-libs is focused more on the implementation of those API's
ah cool, thanks! :)

• "Revert setting a default for the MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET env var for linking" rust#91870
    • fixes rust#91372, a breaking change on macOS targets that prevented compiling against core crates
^ that's a P-critical issue
this seems like an easy beta-accept

• "Fix HashStable implementation on InferTy" rust#91892
    • opened by @Michael Goulet
    • fixes rust#91807 a regression from stable that prevents valid code to compile in Rust 1.57
Err hmm apparently the priority level was never applied?
/me needs to talk to the triage team about still prioritizing closed issues
really we need to fix thnings so that regressions are not closed automatically
we’ve discussed that before. (Was probably even proposed for Meeting proposal, note to self!)
heh, I’m not sure whether we’ve been talking about #91372 or #91807 this whole time
the same thing happened to both, I think. (I.e. both were closed by their respective nightly-only fixes)
but, oh, #91807 is a stable-to-stable regression
I think the same policy should nonetheless apply there.
As in, we need to explicit decide about backporting fixes, even for stable-to-stable regressions, before we close those issues.
I assume that #91807 is not P-critical though
I’m going to mark as P-high

pnkfelix said:

  • "Fix HashStable implementation on InferTy" rust#91892
    • opened by Michael Goulet
    • fixes rust#91807 a regression from stable that prevents valid code to compile in Rust 1.57

looks like we have clear support for beta-accept here

• "Deduplicate projection sub-obligations" rust#90423
    • fixes rust#91598, a P-critical compile-time regression
So, this looks pretty safe
but I’m also totally fine with saying “no, its not worth it here"
I think it is pretty safe but I'd really rather let it ride the beta train.
okay lets just do that
declining for stable backport

T-rustdoc beta / T-rustdoc stable

  • No backport nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

• "Stabilize -Z print-link-args as -C print-link-args" rust#91606
    • @Wesley Wiser proposed merge of the RFC (pending one comment from @Vadim Petrochenkov)
(there’s an RFC checklist about this we mentioned up top)
so I think we can move on

Oldest PRs waiting for review

T-compiler

• "Fix ICE with inferred type in const or static item" rust#89161 (last review activity: about 57 days ago)
    • last review from Niko
lets ping @nikomatsakis and find out if they need more info from the PR author than what the PR author already provided in the github comment thread.
next

• improve type abiguity error for functions and methods rust#89862 (last activity about 2 month ago)
    • PR author @lcnr
    • previously reviewed by @Esteban Küber
    • PR seems to need another round of review
@Esteban Küber do you think someone else should take a look at this? Or are you the right person to look at the revised version?
I’m going to move forward

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 3 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 76 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 51 of those are unassigned
  • 1 P-critical, 1 P-high, 0 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 0 P-critical, 1 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 2 P-critical, 51 P-high, 81 P-medium, 11 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

• "Huge compile-time regression in beta/nightly" rust#91128
    • issue author mentions that disabling the new LLVM pass manager makes the regression disappear
    • an MCVE is at this comment
    • @nikic followed up with some insights and an LLVM patch #D115497
Yeah, I think it's my responsibility in this case
We disabled the new LLVM pass manager, right? Doesn’t that mean we can downgrade rust#91128 ?
Still enabled in nightly and now beta as well since trains rolled over.
I guess the hope is that we resolve this issue and then reenable the passs manager ASAP
Ah ah! okay, thanks for clarification @nagisa
we never landed the PR to disable newPM to master.
I didn’t realize we didn’t disable newPM in master. Okay, okay!
still P-critical then
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/91190
Oh right!
Ha!
nikic's llvm patch just landed upstream: https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/a8c2ba105d47fd9e085ee6f2154005de9888609b
we’re on track to discuss whether to land PR #91190 now or not
Which I think we could backport
I think I like the idea of backporting the LLVM patch
to our nightly
but do we also backport it to beta?
We could backport but only to nightly. Still need to do something about current beta, yeah.
or do we land PR #91190 on beta?
I think reverting newpm on beta is the better idea
That will allow us to get more testing with newpm + nikic's patch
If we're ok waiting another release cycle for the compilation time improvements newpm brought, then I think disabling newpm in beta again and backporting the llvm fix to nightly is the way to go.
In case any other issues (performance or otherwise) shownup
I’m in favor of that plan: disable newpm on beta (presumably via a retargeted PR #91190), and backport the LLVM fix to nightly.
I think we also need to backport actually adding in the llvm option that nikic's patch disables, though
@nagisa , do you have time to own both those tasks?
I think we'll figure something out in wg-llvm. Somebody will surely get around to doing something here.

Aaron Hill said:

I think we also need to backport actually adding in the llvm option that nikic's patch disables, though

huh. because that’s simpler than modifying nikic’s patch, I assume?
Might be me or might be somebody else ^^
Which is commit https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/7abf299fedff2f5b22ea8180311b44feeac26a9f
@nagisa sure, I’m just figuring you own making sure someone does it.
Well, the option didn't exist before
I’m a big fan of everyone delegatinmg

nagisa said:

I think we'll figure something out in wg-llvm. Somebody will surely get around to doing something here.

Please ping me if y'all run out of bandwidth and I'll take over the backports.
Okay I think we’re in good shape here
And we should definitely check with nikic that I haven't misinterpreted anything :)

• "Compile-time regression between 1.56.1 and 1.57.0 for deeply nested decorator types" rust#91598
    • @Aaron Hill provided a fix in PR rust#90423
    • patch is beta- and stable-backport nominated
we addressed this up above, I think.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
Yeah

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • No P-high beta regressions this time.

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs 2021-12-14

This week's report started with 6 regressions; after eliminating truly obvious noise, we are left with just 2 minor regressions. Of the cases that regressed, I think the only interesting one is keccak (regressed by 1.73% in PR #91549). But don't be too depressed: keccak was also improved up to 23% by PR #85013 (!); thanks to @simulacrum for that PR.

Triage done by @pnkfelix.
Revision range: e2116acae59654bfab2a9729a024f3e2fd6d4b02..404c8471aba60c2d837fa728e7c729a0f52d5830

2 Regressions, 5 Improvements, 3 Mixed; 1 of them in rollups
30 Untriaged pull-requests
48 comparisons made in total

Regressions

"Support AVR for inline asm!" #91224

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 0.8% on incr-unchanged builds of externs)
  • This regression is solely isolated to variants of the externs benchmark.
  • It seems like a near certainty that the regression reported here is noise exacerbated by this pathological benchmark.
  • Marked as triaged.

"Eliminate ConstnessAnd again" #91549

  • Large regression in instruction counts (up to 3.1% on full builds of inflate)
  • This PR went through many rounds of performance evaluation and tuning.
  • The only "real" regressions are likely to be inflate and keccak, and I am suspicious of inflate based on its sensitivity in other PR's.
  • I'm leaving this PR in this week's report largely just to draw attention to the problem we face in trying to evalute impact of cases like this.

Improvements

  • "Avoid string validation in rustc_serialize, check a marker byte instead" #91407
  • "Sync portable-simd to remove autosplats" #91484
  • "replace vec::Drain drop loops with drop_in_place" #85157
  • "replace dynamic library module with libloading" #90716
  • "manually implement Hash for DefId" #91660

Mixed

"Replace dominators algorithm with simple Lengauer-Tarjan" #85013

  • Very large improvement in instruction counts (up to -23.6% on full builds of keccak)
  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 0.4% on incr-unchanged builds of helloworld)

"Rollup of 6 pull requests" #91799

  • Very large improvement in instruction counts (up to -5.9% on incr-unchanged builds of inflate)
  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 0.8% on incr-unchanged builds of issue-88862)
  • I don't yet now hat's up with the regression here to issue-88862.

"Deduplicate projection sub-obligations" #90423

  • Very large improvement in instruction counts (up to -6.2% on full builds of deeply-nested)
  • Small regression in instruction counts (up to 0.5% on full builds of regression-31157)
  • This is a targetted fix to address performance regressons that leaked into 1.57. It has been beta-nominated for backport.
We’re discussing the noise from certain benchmarks in #t-compiler/performance > categorize “real world” vs “pathological” benchmarks?

basically, I want to make sure we avoid over-indexing our efforts based on pathological benchmarks that are solely meant to expose certain kinds of bad scenarios (by multiplying certain patterns of code by factors of 100x or 1000x).
when such cases regress by 0.8%, its not nearly as concerning as it is when real world code like diesel or serde regress by 0.8%.
I don't think this is entirely unrealistic though; heavily async code uses lots of nested types
Sure: real world code has patterns and we want to make sure we test those and categorize them as real world.

I don't think this meeting is a good place to debate this thoroughly; my brief comment is that pathological benchmarks that do a lot of a single thing aren't necessarily as pathological as it may seem – real code may do a lot of the same thing (many match arms, deeply nested types, large basic blocks) just as well.
i.e. the reason deeply-nested was added was because there was no async-like benchmark before

pnkfelix said:

when such cases regress by 0.8%, its not nearly as concerning as it is when real world code like diesel or serde regress by 0.8%.

At least some of the pathological benchmarks are meant to catch exponential regressions. Ie externs used to be quadratic in run time or something. We want to avoid going back to that but a linear 10% regression wouldn't necessarily be the end of the world if it improved real world code and was actually only linear.
Speaking of pathological benchmarks, we should make sure something gets added for the issues fixed by projection deduplication
Clearly this is a case where I should turn this into a steering meeting proposal
(way to bring things back full circle!)

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • "Disable LLVM newPM by default" rust#91190
    • mentioned in past meeting, scheduled to be re-evaluated again this week (see comment) and relevant Zulip discussion
    • @Nikita Popov has a patch for LLVM (see relevant comment with some context)
we discussed this up above and I’m very happy with the resolution

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
and with that, we are through the agenda with 5 minutes to spare! Amazing!!!!
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! We can just chatter for five minutes now. :)
And if you have something more you want to talk about, please file a meeting idea!!

next mtg should be on 23rd, Dec
Will it be held?
Is the meeting for next week canceled?
If I can use our extra time to make a short request of any interested parties: #89819 introduces a new dependency for Split DWARF, I'd appreciate thoughts/reviews/etc on that.
That's the day before Christmas eve
Beat me

Jack Huey said:

Beat me

but you're hinting more strongly to the suggested answer :D

davidtwco said:

If I can use our extra time to make a short request of any interested parties: #89819 introduces a new dependency for Split DWARF, I'd appreciate thoughts/reviews/etc on that.

wrote a summary in #t-compiler/wg-incr-comp > #34651 split dwarf progress updates for those looking for context
Do we want to have the meeting after the next one too? Most people who observe these holidays take time off between 24th and the gregorian new year eve too.
Might be best to just take a straw poll. :thumbs_up: if you can make this meeting on the 23rd, :thumbs_down: if you can't/don't want to.
(i can make it, but I think other people should feel free to not come)
:thumbs_up: on this comment if can make it on the 30th, :thumbs_down: if you can't.
I think these things will have an impact on our steering meeting schedule, though
I.e., both of those friday meetings are probably toast.
Yeah, I think that's probably true.
which then leads me to wonder if we should just have an ad hoc steering meteing tomorrow
rather than a planning meeting
if nothing else, we could discuss the pathological/real-world benchmarking stuff tomorrow
That seems reasonable.
@Joshua Nelson @nagisa @Jack Huey do you three think you can make it to tomorrow’s steering meeting slot?
(same time as this one, just on Friday instead of Thursday?)
I think I can, might need to drop off in the middle, though.

pnkfelix said:

(i can make it, but I think other people should feel free to not come)

So based on the strawpoll, I think we should plan to have both triage meetings. I can make both and it sounds like you can as well @pnkfelix. Everyone else is certainly welcome to show up but don't feel like you have to :smile:
Great meeting everyone! What a great start to the day.

davidtwco said:

davidtwco said:

If I can use our extra time to make a short request of any interested parties: #89819 introduces a new dependency for Split DWARF, I'd appreciate thoughts/reviews/etc on that.

wrote a summary in #t-compiler/wg-incr-comp > #34651 split dwarf progress updates for those looking for context

I haven't gotten through my mail backlog to your PR but will eventually ^^

pnkfelix said:

Joshua Nelson nagisa Jack Huey do you three think you can make it to tomorrow’s steering meeting slot?

yes, I can manage that :)
if this is about the perf benchmarks, I highly recommend inviting @simulacrum and @rylev too

pnkfelix said:

Joshua Nelson nagisa Jack Huey do you three think you can make it to tomorrow’s steering meeting slot?

I should be able to

Draft for next week's agenda available at:
https://hackmd.io/HYT7NJFwS8q8Xp1h_CmfTQ?view

Scheduled checkins from:

  • @_WG-self-profile_ from @mw and @Wesley Wiser

Aaron Hill said:

I think we also need to backport actually adding in the llvm option that nikic's patch disables, though

I don't think it is necessary. The option has been added for the purposes of allowing people to turn this functionality back on if they desire to do so. I don't think we can turn it on either way and I think we can live with having people wait until LLVM 14 before they get access to an option like this.
I mean, nikic's first patch adds the functionality to disable the top-down inlining in the first place
Ah, yeah, that's right.
https://github.com/rust-lang/llvm-project/pull/125 is the cherry pick
